<p><strong>The COVID-19 pandemic</strong> has changed consumer behavior. Based on McKinsey surveys of US consumers, many spent the past year trying new brands and channels, adopting in-home alternatives to out-of-home activities, and shifting to online and omnichannel engagement.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="05bd0e47-465b-4aec-bf07-bc43ddad0f65"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="05bd0e47-465b-4aec-bf07-bc43ddad0f65" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jenny Cordina, Eric Levin, and Andrew Ramish, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/helping-us-healthcare-stakeholders-understand-the-human-side-of-the-covid-19-crisis">Helping US healthcare stakeholders understand the human side of the COVID-19 crisis: McKinsey Consumer Healthcare Insights</a>,” January 15, 2021, McKinsey.com; “<a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-us-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis">Survey: US consumer sentiment during the coronavirus crisis</a>,” March 24, 2021, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Many of the shifts could stick after the pandemic, potentially affecting the way that consumers approach healthcare. Consumers are reconsidering how they plan to address mental- and physical-health challenges, how they think about getting healthcare, how they will manage their care needs, and how they expect to do business with healthcare companies, according to McKinsey research based on multiple, nationally representative surveys of US consumers.</p>

<p>To support consumers in those changes, the healthcare ecosystem would likely benefit from accelerating the shift toward making care personal and convenient, using omnichannel methods to reach consumers when and how they want, and improving transparency to support decision making. In this article, we explore five actions that healthcare companies can consider to help improve their engagement with consumers:</p>

<ul>
<li>meeting the needs of the whole person</li>
<li>enabling consumers to make better decisions by providing transparent, understandable information</li>
<li>personalizing and enhancing engagement in healthcare</li>
<li>delivering seamless customer experience across healthcare journeys and coverage transitions, starting with improved access to care</li>
<li>integrating in-person and virtual healthcare solutions</li>
</ul>

<p>While established healthcare players are moving to address these challenges, investors are also backing start-ups in search of innovative solutions. In fact, the first half of 2020 saw a record $5.4 billion in venture funds flowing into digital-healthcare companies, with on-demand healthcare services and monitoring of disease as the top-funded value propositions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8434b635-e9eb-4b54-b3b6-ad8da46005d3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8434b635-e9eb-4b54-b3b6-ad8da46005d3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nina Chiu, Alex Kramer, and Aditya Shah, <em>2020 midyear digital health market update: Unprecedented funding in an unprecedented time</em>, Rock Health, July 2020, rockhealth.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Incumbent payers and providers can consider moves to support consumers in their search for high-quality healthcare. In doing so, they can potentially position themselves to reinforce and build their customer bases as the United States emerges from the pandemic.</p>

<h2>How consumer healthcare demands are changing</h2>

<p>The pandemic has influenced how consumers view and consume healthcare. We have observed several key changes.</p>

<h3>Greater whole-person healthcare-related needs</h3>

<p>Since the COVID-19 pandemic began, consumers have been experiencing worsening health. In a McKinsey survey, around one in five respondents reported lower physical wellness than before the pandemic, while around one in three reported lower emotional wellness.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf006db6-4e97-414d-bbfd-a8e064157c69"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf006db6-4e97-414d-bbfd-a8e064157c69" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Surveys, July 14, 2020, and October 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The economic and employment impact of the COVID-19 crisis has exacerbated that decrease in wellness. Among employees who reported a decrease in employment hours since the start of the pandemic, 32 percent indicated that they exercised less and 27 percent indicated that they gained weight. More than one in three individuals in the group also reported high levels of distress relating to the pandemic, which was nearly eight percentage points higher than the rest of the population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="22647cd4-74f6-412d-adea-ce2f47663e20"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="22647cd4-74f6-412d-adea-ce2f47663e20" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, July 14, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<h3>Changes in how and when consumers get the healthcare they need</h3>

<p>In response to health concerns related to the COVID-19 crisis, more than one in three consumers have demonstrated that they are willing to delay healthcare if they do not feel that physical locations are safe.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5287a28f-386f-4700-9377-514f0ecf084d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5287a28f-386f-4700-9377-514f0ecf084d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, July 14, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> To allay their concerns, providers and payers can consider ways to provide seamless and integrated physical and virtual care. The COVID-19 pandemic has shifted attitudes toward telehealthcare across stakeholders, accelerating the trend toward virtual healthcare. In 2019, 3 percent of survey respondents reported having a telemedicine appointment.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="68b5c904-d4fd-49aa-8daa-e3953afc7f5d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="68b5c904-d4fd-49aa-8daa-e3953afc7f5d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, September 7, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In February 2021, 24 percent of survey respondents reported that their latest medical appointment was conducted through telephonic or virtual means. Further, many consumers may prefer virtual healthcare for mental- and behavioral-healthcare appointments, with 47 percent of consumers reporting that they experienced their most recent appointments virtually and 25 percent reporting that they experienced their most recent appointments by phone.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6e17d46b-8554-4453-86c3-5b100807aeb0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6e17d46b-8554-4453-86c3-5b100807aeb0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, February 19, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> That trend is likely reinforced by the shifting attitudes and policies of other healthcare stakeholders, including providers, payers, and regulators. Before the COVID-19 pandemic, only 4 percent of providers reported that they used telemedicine technology for follow-up care—in part because of a lack of parity in reimbursement compared with in-person healthcare. Providers said in 2020 that they are now using telehealthcare methods more and viewing it more favorably.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4cd10250-93d9-41ec-9ae6-a2da409e3e68"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4cd10250-93d9-41ec-9ae6-a2da409e3e68" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Physician Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> At the same time, healthcare reimbursement is changing to improve its economics and the care covered, both of which are critical to sustained provider use.</p>

<h3>Consumer reconsideration of healthcare-insurance plans and providers</h3>

<p>The COVID-19 crisis has had an impact on how consumers think about the healthcare plans they are using and purchasing, with them reconsidering their options. The economic disruption caused by the crisis has resulted in many consumers losing healthcare-insurance coverage. Of that group, 39 percent had not yet determined if and how to get coverage.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="82f6d3d2-e6e9-4de2-974b-aa25f3056afe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="82f6d3d2-e6e9-4de2-974b-aa25f3056afe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, September 7, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Further, 33 percent of previously uninsured respondents (70 percent of whom earn less than $50,000 per year) reported that they were considering healthcare insurance because of the COVID-19 pandemic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d08bb470-24fd-4640-81eb-ac5234f82154"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d08bb470-24fd-4640-81eb-ac5234f82154" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, July 14, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Our research has found that the pandemic is influencing consumer decision making about which healthcare plans to select. Of respondents who were more likely than their peers to shop for a plan, 49 percent wanted a more affordable plan; 44 percent wanted better coverage, even if a new plan might be more expensive; and 11 percent felt dissatisfied with their insurer’s response to the COVID-19 crisis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d9791f41-9b70-44a6-89d9-cb8ce3c4b1bf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d9791f41-9b70-44a6-89d9-cb8ce3c4b1bf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, June 8, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> While economic uncertainty may likely contribute to consumer demand for more affordable healthcare plans, the health crisis is also creating a need for better coverage and plans that are more responsive to the pandemic. That new demand illustrates how payers can consider improving the personalization of consumer interactions and product recommendations to match divergent consumer needs.</p>

<p>The COVID-19 pandemic also is a factor in consumer decision making related to their providers. Of the 20 percent of respondents without a primary-care provider (PCP), nearly one in three reported an increased interest in obtaining one. Among the 80 percent of respondents who reported having a PCP, 11 percent were considering changing their PCP, primarily because of dissatisfaction with their physicians’ response to the pandemic, a lack of telemedicine appointments, and a lack of communication related to COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="57751677-9f7b-4301-88ca-d1c33685889f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="57751677-9f7b-4301-88ca-d1c33685889f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, June 8, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients">Healthcare Systems & Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>

<h2>How healthcare companies can seek to improve the consumer experience</h2>

<p>The COVID-19 pandemic is shaking up the healthcare landscape. Healthcare payers and providers have an opportunity to serve the changing needs of consumers while potentially setting themselves up for growth when the pandemic ends. They can consider five actions to pursue those opportunities.</p>

<h3>Meet the needs of the whole person and address healthcare equity</h3>

<p>Healthcare companies should consider the needs of the whole person.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1bba3744-0082-4b9e-bf3f-75f9a3adeb51"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1bba3744-0082-4b9e-bf3f-75f9a3adeb51" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See Jenny Cordina, Danielle Feffer, Erica Hutchins Coe, and Seema Parmar, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/understanding-the-impact-of-unmet-social-needs-on-consumer-health-and-healthcare">Understanding the impact of unmet social needs on consumer health and healthcare</a>,” February 20, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Both unmet social needs<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f653b83-5f66-4194-9d34-a063cd5cc584"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f653b83-5f66-4194-9d34-a063cd5cc584" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">An “unmet social need” is defined as the lack of a basic resources, such as food, safe housing, and transportation.</span></span></span></a></span> and poor mental health are linked to poor physical-health outcomes. Respondents who indicated high levels of unmet social needs, stress, and sleep deficiency were 1.5 to 1.8 times more likely than peers to report having visited an emergency room in the past year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ebaa64ac-b7e3-4a09-bd8b-49796e6f51f0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ebaa64ac-b7e3-4a09-bd8b-49796e6f51f0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Respondents with multiple unmet social needs and self-reported poor mental health were around 2.75 times as likely as those with no unmet social needs to indicate high healthcare utilization.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="815d7a4c-3735-4ac3-9b27-93f412422c0a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="815d7a4c-3735-4ac3-9b27-93f412422c0a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>The relationship between social needs and physical health is important, as more than two in five individuals have at least one unmet social need. The proportion varies by type of health insurance, with 65 percent of respondents with Medicaid coverage reporting at least one unmet social need, compared with 31 percent of those with Medicare coverage.</p>

<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to focus on whole person health and to address the behavioral, social, and economic vulnerabilities of the healthcare system.</p></blockquote></div>

<p>Given the disproportionately high impact of unmet social needs on certain races and ethnicities, addressing basic needs will also be a critical step toward health equity. In the 2020 McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 51 percent and 53 percent of Black and Latino respondents, respectively, reported at least one unmet social need, compared with 39 percent of white respondents.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ad7cceac-0fcb-4f24-a30a-1c2f246eeeb7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ad7cceac-0fcb-4f24-a30a-1c2f246eeeb7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Moreover, 70 percent of Latino and 63 percent of Black respondents said they were satisfied with their healthcare-insurance company, compared with 73 percent of white respondents, while 69 percent of Latino and 76 percent of Black respondents are satisfied with their PCPs, compared with 81 percent of white respondents.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="824172ad-990b-4f98-827d-29b117a58029"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="824172ad-990b-4f98-827d-29b117a58029" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Consumer Survey, September 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to focus on whole-person health and to address the behavioral, social, and economic vulnerabilities of the healthcare system. For instance, people with behavioral-health conditions make up 25 percent of the general population, but 47 percent of those are at risk for severe COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="33ee7b3d-1db1-411e-8bf1-708315b0a1e4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="33ee7b3d-1db1-411e-8bf1-708315b0a1e4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Center for Societal Benefit through Healthcare by McKinsey, <a href="https://csbh-dashboard.mckinsey.com/#/#/">CSBH-Dashboard.McKinsey.com</a>.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, although only 15 percent of people live in areas with significant unmet social needs, 28 percent of COVID-19-related deaths occurred in those areas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7481187b-cdff-49c6-a80f-3788b91c821f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7481187b-cdff-49c6-a80f-3788b91c821f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Social determinants of health data, Algorex Health Technologies; Center for Societal Benefit through Healthcare by McKinsey, <a href="https://csbh-dashboard.mckinsey.com/#/#/">CSBH-Dashboard.McKinsey.com</a>.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>To address those issues, healthcare payers and providers could consider the following initiatives:</p>

<ul>
<li>optimizing healthcare offerings to meet broader needs by coordinating behavioral-, social-, and physical-healthcare services—for example, some payers are evaluating investments in affordable housing and technology tools that connect healthcare providers to community-health stakeholders</li>
<li>expanding behavioral-health and social services, such as improved access points and broader offerings across the care continuum—for example, some payers are beginning to launch partnerships with retailers to improve screening for social determinants of health</li>
<li>increasing awareness of behavioral health and social needs and expanding workplace supports for those needs for employees—our research has found that 23 percent of employers reported that they planned to start or increase wellness- or mindfulness-support services<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d0c0c5c4-8976-4355-b8a5-a5fee9d6611a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d0c0c5c4-8976-4355-b8a5-a5fee9d6611a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey COVID-19 Employer Health Benefits Survey, April 16, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>

<p>Leading healthcare payers, healthcare providers, and employers are investing in start-ups and partnering with innovative vendors to deliver complete healthcare solutions to consumers. Some examples of vendors include Cityblock Health, which offers community-based care for low-income consumers, and Quartet Health, which enables integrated care for patients with chronic medical and behavioral-health conditions.</p>

<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-md-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Leading healthcare payers, healthcare providers, and employers are investing in start-ups and partnering with innovative vendors to deliver complete healthcare solutions to consumers.</p></blockquote></div>

<h3>Help consumers make better decisions by providing transparent, understandable information</h3>

<p>One in four survey respondents reported that they were frustrated by higher-than-expected healthcare costs, despite many years of efforts toward improvement by healthcare companies. Higher-than-expected cost of service was the number-one frustration with payers and the number-two frustration with providers. A perceived lack of cost transparency can potentially drive consumer behavior. Members of healthcare payers that are considered the best in class for consumer experience are 58 percent less likely to report postponing care because of a lack of information than are members of less-effective payers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f818171b-8156-4c88-abb9-96247a2050ed"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f818171b-8156-4c88-abb9-96247a2050ed" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See Jenny Cordina and Sarah Greenberg, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/consumer-decision-making-in-healthcare-the-role-of-information-transparency">Consumer decision making in healthcare: The role of information transparency</a>,” July 13, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>To help consumers make better decisions, healthcare companies can consider the following:</p>

<ul>
<li>incentivizing consumers to look up healthcare information and conduct research to see how much a service or visit would cost—only 40 percent of respondents reported conducting research on healthcare-service and -visit costs, representing a large opportunity for payers to promote better decision making<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e4075825-8678-4d27-9276-0d3db03b3a82"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e4075825-8678-4d27-9276-0d3db03b3a82" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Payer Customer Experience Survey, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
<li>making it easier for consumers to understand information, including total costs, through personalized and more straightforward navigation—among respondents who conducted research on healthcare services and visits, 15 percent were unable to find cost information<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a6a17fa0-2c9c-4ba5-b80f-e3d87ae7234b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a6a17fa0-2c9c-4ba5-b80f-e3d87ae7234b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Payer Customer Experience Survey, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
<li>collaborating across the ecosystem in sharing appropriate information—only 8 percent of physicians reported knowing what their patients’ out-of-pocket costs were, and fewer than 15 percent of providers that wanted to know about their patients’ out-of-pocket costs reported having access to that information<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5e88835d-28b0-4a67-a306-5abc4ef89bf7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5e88835d-28b0-4a67-a306-5abc4ef89bf7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Physician Survey, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="COVID-19 Consumer Healthcare Insights: What 2021 may hold" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/covid%2019%20consumer%20healthcare%20insights%20what%202021%20may%20hold/standard-2021-outlook.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>COVID-19 Consumer Healthcare Insights: What 2021 may hold</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/covid-19-consumer-healthcare-insights-what-2021-may-hold" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>

<h3>Personalize and enhance engagement in healthcare</h3>

<p>Data strongly suggest that personalized healthcare improves the patient experience, with implications for both payers and providers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="901b4c7e-4059-40c6-a539-42bd59cf319b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="901b4c7e-4059-40c6-a539-42bd59cf319b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See Jenny Cordina, Greg Gilbert, Nevada Griffin, and Rohit Kumar, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/next-generation-member-engagement-during-the-care-journey">Next-generation member engagement during the care journey</a>,” July 23, 2019, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> For example, respondents with unplanned high-cost follow-up care are 2.2 times more likely to change their insurance plans than are respondents with routine follow-up care.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="096d1e8c-c76a-4309-a6c4-b4c6102ddc68"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="096d1e8c-c76a-4309-a6c4-b4c6102ddc68" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Patient Engagement Survey, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Personalized healthcare may also promote better outcomes by enabling patients to make the right decisions at the right time along their care journeys, taking into account their attitudes and holistic needs. For example, respondents who indicated that they received clear postdischarge instructions were less likely to report unplanned high-cost follow-up care than were their peers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a663a675-ab5f-437d-b784-5bcf214f4ab8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a663a675-ab5f-437d-b784-5bcf214f4ab8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Patient Engagement Survey, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> That correlation was particularly significant among respondents who indicated lower levels of health-conscious attitudes—a clear sign that those types of patients may benefit from engagement and the right models to get the right information to avoid poor health outcomes, potentially.</p>

<p>More than one in four survey respondents highlighted frustrations of not feeling listened to or not being able to meet administrative needs, such as scheduling appointments at convenient times.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="65526fac-606c-4f69-880e-1576670b7c98"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="65526fac-606c-4f69-880e-1576670b7c98" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Beyond tactical efforts to improve scheduling availability, the COVID-19 pandemic has also shown that both payers and providers could improve the empathetic nature of their consumer interactions through tactics such as coaching, knowledge sharing, and job aids that include questions designed to elicit consumer needs.</p>

<p>To deliver personalized care and better engage consumers through their care journeys, healthcare companies could consider renewing their commitment to the following:</p>

<ul>
<li>enabling patients to make the right decisions at the right time</li>
<li>listening to and understanding consumers’ needs and treating them with respect</li>
<li>creating a safe physical environment that seamlessly integrates with a patient’s care ecosystem—a concern that is particularly relevant in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic</li>
</ul>

<h3>Deliver seamless customer experience across healthcare journeys and coverage transitions, starting with access to care</h3>

<p>As many consumers are already experiencing or expecting to experience transitions in healthcare coverage because of the COVID-19 pandemic, they are increasingly considering their options when it comes to choosing a healthcare-insurance plan or selecting where to get care. By supporting consumers in making those decisions and transitions, healthcare companies could empower customers while potentially improving retention and spurring growth.</p>

<p>Members who reported being satisfied with their insurance-shopping or -renewal experience were 40 to 75 percentage points more likely to consider that insurer (Exhibit 1).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="95018397-ab2e-459f-9a50-130bfa9b2766"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="95018397-ab2e-459f-9a50-130bfa9b2766" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Government Markets Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Based on an analysis of survey responses, the most important factors underpinning respondent satisfaction with their shopping or renewal experiences were convenience, easy comparison of options, and transparency of out-of-pocket costs. Surprisingly, just two in five members who switched health-insurance plans reported being contacted by their original insurers about plan renewal.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e25dd406-b7da-41ac-addc-017a099d564a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e25dd406-b7da-41ac-addc-017a099d564a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Government Markets Survey, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/how%20covid%2019%20has%20changed%20the%20way%20us%20consumers%20think%20about%20healthcare/svg-covid-howconsumersviewhealthcare_ex1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Customer satisfaction drives repeat business for healthcare insurer." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/how%20covid%2019%20has%20changed%20the%20way%20us%20consumers%20think%20about%20healthcare/svg-covid-howconsumersviewhealthcare_ex1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Healthcare payers could consider taking actions to make those moves as seamless as possible by helping consumers transition into the products that best fit their needs. Such actions will likely require a step change in engagement both in the analytics (to understand likely consumer needs and preferences) and the tactical engagement across channels. Specifically, healthcare companies could consider the following:</p>

<ul>
<li>providing personalized, easy-to-understand information—for instance, clear explanations regarding any change in benefit design</li>
<li>delivering information that is relevant to the decision—for example, the number-one request of survey respondents was for providers to offer greater availability of appointments to enable consumers to be seen when, how, and with whom they wanted<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b2059b1b-413e-4623-b31e-72b713ddb323"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b2059b1b-413e-4623-b31e-72b713ddb323" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
<li>enhancing the ease of navigation and functionality of websites and apps, making it easier for consumers to engage with healthcare companies across channels</li>
</ul>

<h3>Integrate in-person and virtual healthcare solutions</h3>

<p>Consumers increasingly prefer digital channels across all healthcare-related activities, ranging from choosing a health plan, provider, and pharmacy to receiving the care they need and managing administrative actions and finances.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="929498b5-f08e-4fac-9eda-a47191aa1387"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="929498b5-f08e-4fac-9eda-a47191aa1387" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See Oleg Bestsennyy, Greg Gilbert, Alex Harris, and Jennifer Rost, “<a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/telehealth-a-quarter-trillion-dollar-post-covid-19-reality">Telehealth: A quarter-trillion-dollar post-COVID-19 reality?</a>,” May 29, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> In 2016, just over one-half to two-thirds of survey respondents preferred digital solutions to many of the activities they were doing across their healthcare journeys. In 2020, 70 to 80 percent of respondents reported looking to do those same activities digitally.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e92f4fb7-c53f-42a0-ba45-04521c87d939"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e92f4fb7-c53f-42a0-ba45-04521c87d939" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> The trend toward digital is not limited to younger consumers. Baby boomers, for instance, reported preferring digital healthcare at higher rates than the general population did.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d4aab218-c01b-4d64-a669-cb1b0d19fe91"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d4aab218-c01b-4d64-a669-cb1b0d19fe91" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In healthcare, digital use is still far lower than is consumer demand (Exhibit 2). In fact, 42 percent of respondents indicated that there weren’t any healthcare websites or applications that currently did a good job.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b133787d-c40f-4395-a2d0-56070daad44b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b133787d-c40f-4395-a2d0-56070daad44b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Some of the largest opportunities to increase digital use include monitoring health metrics, searching for healthcare-provider costs, and scheduling appointments online. The COVID-19 pandemic has revealed a unique opportunity for healthcare companies to expand virtual healthcare solutions and offer integrated care.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/how%20covid%2019%20has%20changed%20the%20way%20us%20consumers%20think%20about%20healthcare/svg-covid-howconsumersviewhealthcare_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Although three-quarters of healthcare consumers say they prefer digital tools, just one-quarter report currently using them." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/how%20covid%2019%20has%20changed%20the%20way%20us%20consumers%20think%20about%20healthcare/svg-covid-howconsumersviewhealthcare_ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>To integrate in-person and virtual healthcare further, healthcare companies could consider the following:</p>

<ul>
<li>creating consumer-centric digital solutions that will encourage digital engagement; the solutions may need to be tailored by type of consumer—for instance, older respondents observed that website graphics were hard for them to read and were complicated to navigate<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c5a02bbe-212f-49ab-8269-ee761157c50b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c5a02bbe-212f-49ab-8269-ee761157c50b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Government Markets Survey, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
<li>delivering care in a cohesive and integrated way as part of an integrated care plan—consumers are open to this integration, with 51 percent of respondents indicating that they had interest in using a digital tool to track their health information and share with their doctors,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="171ccb74-6e40-4111-a831-7cda82d876c6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="171ccb74-6e40-4111-a831-7cda82d876c6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> and providers could have a role to play in ensuring that the integration takes place</li>
<li>considering reimbursement changes and structural modifications to support new ways of delivering care across virtual services, new retail-oriented models, and traditional-care pathways—because of the COVID-19 pandemic, many payers have committed to expanding their coverage of and reimbursement for telehealthcare services, which will likely be an important enabler of their greater adoption among providers and consumers</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has reset the way many consumers feel about, think about, and interact with their healthcare providers, with more expectations of higher levels of personalization and engagement. Healthcare players across the value chain have an opportunity to engage and support consumers better to ensure that they continue to receive high-quality care. Healthcare companies that live up to that higher bar may not only satisfy their customers and create improved healthcare outcomes but also be best positioned to retain and increase their customer bases as the pandemic ebbs.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" healthcare","displayName":"How COVID 19 has changed the way US consumers think about healthcare","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"71f63418-660d-44e1-9883-8a08a905cafb","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"How COVID-19 has changed the way US consumers think about healthcare"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"COVID-19 and how consumers think about healthcare"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Taking five actions can help US healthcare payers and providers improve their engagement with consumers."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-06-04T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\n\u003cp \u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic\u003c/strong\u003e has changed consumer behavior. Based on McKinsey surveys of US consumers, many spent the past year trying new brands and channels, adopting in-home alternatives to out-of-home activities, and shifting to online and omnichannel engagement.[[footnote 1]] Many of the shifts could stick after the pandemic, potentially affecting the way that consumers approach healthcare. Consumers are reconsidering how they plan to address mental- and physical-health challenges, how they think about getting healthcare, how they will manage their care needs, and how they expect to do business with healthcare companies, according to McKinsey research based on multiple, nationally representative surveys of US consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo support consumers in those changes, the healthcare ecosystem would likely benefit from accelerating the shift toward making care personal and convenient, using omnichannel methods to reach consumers when and how they want, and improving transparency to support decision making. In this article, we explore five actions that healthcare companies can consider to help improve their engagement with consumers:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003emeeting the needs of the whole person\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eenabling consumers to make better decisions by providing transparent, understandable information\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003epersonalizing and enhancing engagement in healthcare\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003edelivering seamless customer experience across healthcare journeys and coverage transitions, starting with improved access to care\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eintegrating in-person and virtual healthcare solutions\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWhile established healthcare players are moving to address these challenges, investors are also backing start-ups in search of innovative solutions. In fact, the first half of 2020 saw a record $5.4 billion in venture funds flowing into digital-healthcare companies, with on-demand healthcare services and monitoring of disease as the top-funded value propositions.[[footnote 2]] Incumbent payers and providers can consider moves to support consumers in their search for high-quality healthcare. In doing so, they can potentially position themselves to reinforce and build their customer bases as the United States emerges from the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eHow consumer healthcare demands are changing\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe pandemic has influenced how consumers view and consume healthcare. We have observed several key changes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eGreater whole-person healthcare-related needs\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSince the COVID-19 pandemic began, consumers have been experiencing worsening health. In a McKinsey survey, around one in five respondents reported lower physical wellness than before the pandemic, while around one in three reported lower emotional wellness.[[footnote 3]] The economic and employment impact of the COVID-19 crisis has exacerbated that decrease in wellness. Among employees who reported a decrease in employment hours since the start of the pandemic, 32 percent indicated that they exercised less and 27 percent indicated that they gained weight. More than one in three individuals in the group also reported high levels of distress relating to the pandemic, which was nearly eight percentage points higher than the rest of the population.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eChanges in how and when consumers get the healthcare they need\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn response to health concerns related to the COVID-19 crisis, more than one in three consumers have demonstrated that they are willing to delay healthcare if they do not feel that physical locations are safe.[[footnote 5]] To allay their concerns, providers and payers can consider ways to provide seamless and integrated physical and virtual care. The COVID-19 pandemic has shifted attitudes toward telehealthcare across stakeholders, accelerating the trend toward virtual healthcare. In 2019, 3 percent of survey respondents reported having a telemedicine appointment.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn February 2021, 24 percent of survey respondents reported that their latest medical appointment was conducted through telephonic or virtual means. Further, many consumers may prefer virtual healthcare for mental- and behavioral-healthcare appointments, with 47 percent of consumers reporting that they experienced their most recent appointments virtually and 25 percent reporting that they experienced their most recent appointments by phone.[[footnote 7]] That trend is likely reinforced by the shifting attitudes and policies of other healthcare stakeholders, including providers, payers, and regulators. Before the COVID-19 pandemic, only 4 percent of providers reported that they used telemedicine technology for follow-up care\u0026mdash;in part because of a lack of parity in reimbursement compared with in-person healthcare. Providers said in 2020 that they are now using telehealthcare methods more and viewing it more favorably.[[footnote 8]] At the same time, healthcare reimbursement is changing to improve its economics and the care covered, both of which are critical to sustained provider use.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eConsumer reconsideration of healthcare-insurance plans and providers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 crisis has had an impact on how consumers think about the healthcare plans they are using and purchasing, with them reconsidering their options. The economic disruption caused by the crisis has resulted in many consumers losing healthcare-insurance coverage. Of that group, 39 percent had not yet determined if and how to get coverage.[[footnote 9]] Further, 33 percent of previously uninsured respondents (70 percent of whom earn less than $50,000 per year) reported that they were considering healthcare insurance because of the COVID-19 pandemic.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOur research has found that the pandemic is influencing consumer decision making about which healthcare plans to select. Of respondents who were more likely than their peers to shop for a plan, 49 percent wanted a more affordable plan; 44 percent wanted better coverage, even if a new plan might be more expensive; and 11 percent felt dissatisfied with their insurer\u0026rsquo;s response to the COVID-19 crisis.[[footnote 11]] While economic uncertainty may likely contribute to consumer demand for more affordable healthcare plans, the health crisis is also creating a need for better coverage and plans that are more responsive to the pandemic. That new demand illustrates how payers can consider improving the personalization of consumer interactions and product recommendations to match divergent consumer needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic also is a factor in consumer decision making related to their providers. Of the 20 percent of respondents without a primary-care provider (PCP), nearly one in three reported an increased interest in obtaining one. Among the 80 percent of respondents who reported having a PCP, 11 percent were considering changing their PCP, primarily because of dissatisfaction with their physicians\u0026rsquo; response to the pandemic, a lack of telemedicine appointments, and a lack of communication related to COVID-19.[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[disruptor1up learnmore]]\n\n\u003ch2\u003eHow healthcare companies can seek to improve the consumer experience\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic is shaking up the healthcare landscape. Healthcare payers and providers have an opportunity to serve the changing needs of consumers while potentially setting themselves up for growth when the pandemic ends. They can consider five actions to pursue those opportunities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eMeet the needs of the whole person and address healthcare equity\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHealthcare companies should consider the needs of the whole person.[[footnote 13]] Both unmet social needs[[footnote 14]] and poor mental health are linked to poor physical-health outcomes. Respondents who indicated high levels of unmet social needs, stress, and sleep deficiency were 1.5 to 1.8 times more likely than peers to report having visited an emergency room in the past year.[[footnote 15]] Respondents with multiple unmet social needs and self-reported poor mental health were around 2.75 times as likely as those with no unmet social needs to indicate high healthcare utilization.[[footnote 16]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe relationship between social needs and physical health is important, as more than two in five individuals have at least one unmet social need. The proportion varies by type of health insurance, with 65 percent of respondents with Medicaid coverage reporting at least one unmet social need, compared with 31 percent of those with Medicare coverage.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eGiven the disproportionately high impact of unmet social needs on certain races and ethnicities, addressing basic needs will also be a critical step toward health equity. In the 2020 McKinsey Consumer Health Insights Survey, 51 percent and 53 percent of Black and Latino respondents, respectively, reported at least one unmet social need, compared with 39 percent of white respondents.[[footnote 17]] Moreover, 70 percent of Latino and 63 percent of Black respondents said they were satisfied with their healthcare-insurance company, compared with 73 percent of white respondents, while 69 percent of Latino and 76 percent of Black respondents are satisfied with their PCPs, compared with 81 percent of white respondents.[[footnote 18]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to focus on whole-person health and to address the behavioral, social, and economic vulnerabilities of the healthcare system. For instance, people with behavioral-health conditions make up 25 percent of the general population, but 47 percent of those are at risk for severe COVID-19.[[footnote 19]] In addition, although only 15 percent of people live in areas with significant unmet social needs, 28 percent of COVID-19-related deaths occurred in those areas.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo address those issues, healthcare payers and providers could consider the following initiatives:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eoptimizing healthcare offerings to meet broader needs by coordinating behavioral-, social-, and physical-healthcare services\u0026mdash;for example, some payers are evaluating investments in affordable housing and technology tools that connect healthcare providers to community-health stakeholders\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eexpanding behavioral-health and social services, such as improved access points and broader offerings across the care continuum\u0026mdash;for example, some payers are beginning to launch partnerships with retailers to improve screening for social determinants of health\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eincreasing awareness of behavioral health and social needs and expanding workplace supports for those needs for employees\u0026mdash;our research has found that 23 percent of employers reported that they planned to start or increase wellness- or mindfulness-support services[[footnote 21]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eLeading healthcare payers, healthcare providers, and employers are investing in start-ups and partnering with innovative vendors to deliver complete healthcare solutions to consumers. Some examples of vendors include Cityblock Health, which offers community-based care for low-income consumers, and Quartet Health, which enables integrated care for patients with chronic medical and behavioral-health conditions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 2]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eHelp consumers make better decisions by providing transparent, understandable information\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOne in four survey respondents reported that they were frustrated by higher-than-expected healthcare costs, despite many years of efforts toward improvement by healthcare companies. Higher-than-expected cost of service was the number-one frustration with payers and the number-two frustration with providers. A perceived lack of cost transparency can potentially drive consumer behavior. Members of healthcare payers that are considered the best in class for consumer experience are 58 percent less likely to report postponing care because of a lack of information than are members of less-effective payers.[[footnote 22]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo help consumers make better decisions, healthcare companies can consider the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eincentivizing consumers to look up healthcare information and conduct research to see how much a service or visit would cost\u0026mdash;only 40 percent of respondents reported conducting research on healthcare-service and -visit costs, representing a large opportunity for payers to promote better decision making[[footnote 23]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003emaking it easier for consumers to understand information, including total costs, through personalized and more straightforward navigation\u0026mdash;among respondents who conducted research on healthcare services and visits, 15 percent were unable to find cost information[[footnote 24]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ecollaborating across the ecosystem in sharing appropriate information\u0026mdash;only 8 percent of physicians reported knowing what their patients\u0026rsquo; out-of-pocket costs were, and fewer than 15 percent of providers that wanted to know about their patients\u0026rsquo; out-of-pocket costs reported having access to that information[[footnote 25]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003ePersonalize and enhance engagement in healthcare\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eData strongly suggest that personalized healthcare improves the patient experience, with implications for both payers and providers.[[footnote 26]] For example, respondents with unplanned high-cost follow-up care are 2.2 times more likely to change their insurance plans than are respondents with routine follow-up care.[[footnote 27]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003ePersonalized healthcare may also promote better outcomes by enabling patients to make the right decisions at the right time along their care journeys, taking into account their attitudes and holistic needs. For example, respondents who indicated that they received clear postdischarge instructions were less likely to report unplanned high-cost follow-up care than were their peers.[[footnote 28]] That correlation was particularly significant among respondents who indicated lower levels of health-conscious attitudes\u0026mdash;a clear sign that those types of patients may benefit from engagement and the right models to get the right information to avoid poor health outcomes, potentially.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eMore than one in four survey respondents highlighted frustrations of not feeling listened to or not being able to meet administrative needs, such as scheduling appointments at convenient times.[[footnote 29]] Beyond tactical efforts to improve scheduling availability, the COVID-19 pandemic has also shown that both payers and providers could improve the empathetic nature of their consumer interactions through tactics such as coaching, knowledge sharing, and job aids that include questions designed to elicit consumer needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo deliver personalized care and better engage consumers through their care journeys, healthcare companies could consider renewing their commitment to the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eenabling patients to make the right decisions at the right time\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003elistening to and understanding consumers\u0026rsquo; needs and treating them with respect\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ecreating a safe physical environment that seamlessly integrates with a patient\u0026rsquo;s care ecosystem\u0026mdash;a concern that is particularly relevant in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eDeliver seamless customer experience across healthcare journeys and coverage transitions, starting with access to care\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAs many consumers are already experiencing or expecting to experience transitions in healthcare coverage because of the COVID-19 pandemic, they are increasingly considering their options when it comes to choosing a healthcare-insurance plan or selecting where to get care. By supporting consumers in making those decisions and transitions, healthcare companies could empower customers while potentially improving retention and spurring growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eMembers who reported being satisfied with their insurance-shopping or -renewal experience were 40 to 75 percentage points more likely to consider that insurer (Exhibit 1).[[footnote 30]] Based on an analysis of survey responses, the most important factors underpinning respondent satisfaction with their shopping or renewal experiences were convenience, easy comparison of options, and transparency of out-of-pocket costs. Surprisingly, just two in five members who switched health-insurance plans reported being contacted by their original insurers about plan renewal.[[footnote 31]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eHealthcare payers could consider taking actions to make those moves as seamless as possible by helping consumers transition into the products that best fit their needs. Such actions will likely require a step change in engagement both in the analytics (to understand likely consumer needs and preferences) and the tactical engagement across channels. Specifically, healthcare companies could consider the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eproviding personalized, easy-to-understand information\u0026mdash;for instance, clear explanations regarding any change in benefit design\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003edelivering information that is relevant to the decision\u0026mdash;for example, the number-one request of survey respondents was for providers to offer greater availability of appointments to enable consumers to be seen when, how, and with whom they wanted[[footnote 32]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eenhancing the ease of navigation and functionality of websites and apps, making it easier for consumers to engage with healthcare companies across channels\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eIntegrate in-person and virtual healthcare solutions\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers increasingly prefer digital channels across all healthcare-related activities, ranging from choosing a health plan, provider, and pharmacy to receiving the care they need and managing administrative actions and finances.[[footnote 33]] In 2016, just over one-half to two-thirds of survey respondents preferred digital solutions to many of the activities they were doing across their healthcare journeys. In 2020, 70 to 80 percent of respondents reported looking to do those same activities digitally.[[footnote 34]] The trend toward digital is not limited to younger consumers. Baby boomers, for instance, reported preferring digital healthcare at higher rates than the general population did.[[footnote 35]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn healthcare, digital use is still far lower than is consumer demand (Exhibit 2). In fact, 42 percent of respondents indicated that there weren\u0026rsquo;t any healthcare websites or applications that currently did a good job.[[footnote 36]] Some of the largest opportunities to increase digital use include monitoring health metrics, searching for healthcare-provider costs, and scheduling appointments online. The COVID-19 pandemic has revealed a unique opportunity for healthcare companies to expand virtual healthcare solutions and offer integrated care.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo integrate in-person and virtual healthcare further, healthcare companies could consider the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ecreating consumer-centric digital solutions that will encourage digital engagement; the solutions may need to be tailored by type of consumer\u0026mdash;for instance, older respondents observed that website graphics were hard for them to read and were complicated to navigate[[footnote 37]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003edelivering care in a cohesive and integrated way as part of an integrated care plan\u0026mdash;consumers are open to this integration, with 51 percent of respondents indicating that they had interest in using a digital tool to track their health information and share with their doctors,[[footnote 38]] and providers could have a role to play in ensuring that the integration takes place\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003econsidering reimbursement changes and structural modifications to support new ways of delivering care across virtual services, new retail-oriented models, and traditional-care pathways\u0026mdash;because of the COVID-19 pandemic, many payers have committed to expanding their coverage of and reimbursement for telehealthcare services, which will likely be an important enabler of their greater adoption among providers and consumers\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\n[[sidebar disclaim]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic has reset the way many consumers feel about, think about, and interact with their healthcare providers, with more expectations of higher levels of personalization and engagement. Healthcare players across the value chain have an opportunity to engage and support consumers better to ensure that they continue to receive high-quality care. Healthcare companies that live up to that higher bar may not only satisfy their customers and create improved healthcare outcomes but also be best positioned to retain and increase their customer bases as the pandemic
